title: Tyrann Mathieu suggests Patriots learn from Chiefs' Super Bowl LV loss
description: Tyrann Mathieu suggests the New England Patriots learn from the Kansas City Chiefs' Super Bowl LV loss | @EdEastonJr
fullText:
The Kansas City Chiefs' loss to the Tampa Bay Buccaneers in Super Bowl LV forced an offseason change to improve the offensive line's protection of Patrick Mahomes. The adjustment was witnessed firsthand by former safety Tyrann Mathieu, who believes the same standards should apply to the New England Patriots.

The three-time Pro Bowler spoke about the situation during a recent episode of his podcast 'In the Bayou with Tyrann Mathieu'.

"New England should take sort of the Kansas City Chiefs approach. After we lost [Super Bowl LV]‚Ä¶ the very next day, they got new offensive linemen," said Mathieu, "You gotta be able to protect the product."

Tyrann Mathieu‚Äôs thoughts on the #Patriots Super Bowl loss:

‚ÄúNew England should take sort of the Kansas City Chiefs approach. After we lost [the Super Bowl]‚Ä¶ the very next day, they got new offensive linemen‚Ä¶ You gotta be able to protect the product.‚Äù

(üé• @InTheBayouPod) pic.twitter.com/W8bIB1kAJE

‚Äî Carlos A. Lopez (@LosTalksPats) February 16, 2026

Mathieu's comments echo those of many who watched the Seattle Seahawks defense dominate the Patriots' offensive line in Super Bowl LX. Left tackle Will Campbell was the target of much of the criticism, although he had an impressive season.

The Chiefs notably signed Orlando Brown Jr., Joe Thuney, and Kyle Long after Super Bowl LV to vastly improve their offensive line for the following season. New England is expected to focus on Drake Maye's protection during the offseason after he was sacked an NFL record 21 times during the 2025 postseason.

This article originally appeared on Chiefs Wire: Tyrann Mathieu suggests Patriots learn from Chiefs' Super Bowl LV loss

title: Patrick Mahomes and Travis Kelce facing lawsuit over their Kansas City steakhouse
description: Patrick Mahomes and Travis Kelce are dealing with a lawsuit tied to the name of their Kansas City restaurant, 1587 Prime. A sneaker brand has filed a trademark infringement claim against the Chiefs teammates and their restaurant partners, asserting that the use of ‚Äú1587‚Äù conflicts with its own branding.
fullText:
Patrick Mahomes and Travis Kelce are dealing with a lawsuit tied to the name of their Kansas City restaurant, 1587 Prime.

A sneaker brand has filed a trademark infringement claim against the Chiefs teammates and their restaurant partners, asserting that the use of ‚Äú1587‚Äù conflicts with its own branding.

At the center of the dispute is the shared number combination used by both businesses. The legal battle now hinges on whether the two brands can operate under similar marks in different industries.

The complaint was brought by 1587 Sneakers, which says it began selling footwear under that name on April 13, 2023.

The restaurant‚Äôs title merges Mahomes‚Äô No. 15 and Kelce‚Äôs No. 87, a pairing the sneaker company argues it had already established in commerce.

Court records show that 1587 Prime applied for its trademark in December 2023 in the restaurant category, while 1587 Sneakers filed its application last October in the clothing category.

The sneaker brand claims that ‚Äúscores of consumers‚Äù have reached out believing the two ventures are connected.

The lawsuit seeks to bar the restaurant group from continuing to use the 1587 branding, halt the sale of related merchandise, and secure unspecified damages.

Josh Gerben, a trademark attorney not involved in the matter, indicated the sneaker company could face challenges proving infringement.

He noted that trademarks are often allowed to coexist across separate business sectors unless consumer confusion is clearly shown.

‚ÄúI think it‚Äôs a tough case for the sneaker company,‚Äù Gerben said. ‚ÄúTrademarks can coexist in different industries. ‚Ä¶ Given that the marks are essentially identical here, is a restaurant and a shoe company too close? Are consumers likely to be confused in thinking they are affiliated with one another?‚Äù

A publicist for Kelce declined to comment, and a representative for Mahomes did not respond to inquiries. The outcome will determine whether the restaurant can continue operating under its current name.

title: Kansas City Chiefs HC Andy Reid drops latest update on Travis Kelce‚Äôs future
description: Kansas City Chiefs head coach Andy Reid has offered a fresh update on Travis Kelce‚Äôs future, stressing that open dialogue remains the most important factor as speculation continues. The veteran tight end has faced renewed questions about how much longer he plans to play, particularly after another demanding postseason run.
fullText:
Kansas City Chiefs head coach Andy Reid has offered a fresh update on Travis Kelce‚Äôs future, stressing that open dialogue remains the most important factor as speculation continues.

The veteran tight end has faced renewed questions about how much longer he plans to play, particularly after another demanding postseason run.

Reid‚Äôs latest comments suggest the situation is stable rather than urgent.

Per ESPN, Reid said, ‚ÄúThere is communication. That‚Äôs the main thing. I‚Äôve said this before: As long as there‚Äôs communication, I‚Äôm good.

‚ÄúThat means people want to move forward. I think that‚Äôs where Travis is.‚Äù

The Chiefs have leaned heavily on Kelce throughout their recent Super Bowl runs, with the tight end remaining Patrick Mahomes‚Äô most trusted target in critical moments.

At 36, Kelce continues to produce at a high level, but the physical demands of the position inevitably prompt discussion about longevity.

Reid‚Äôs emphasis on communication indicates there is no disconnect between player and organisation. Instead, both sides appear aligned in assessing what comes next.

Reid added: ‚ÄúI‚Äôm not trying to put words in his mouth at all, and I try to give him some space here. He‚Äôs been doing this a long time, and he can sort all that out as he goes forward.

‚ÄúBut we‚Äôre proceeding with that.‚Äù

The head coach‚Äôs tone reflects respect for a player who has become central to the franchise‚Äôs modern era.

Kelce‚Äôs resume includes multiple Super Bowl titles and consistent Pro Bowl selections, placing him among the most accomplished tight ends in NFL history.

For now, the message from Kansas City is clear: discussions are ongoing, and the relationship remains strong.

title: Chiefs set to do something cool for fans this offseason
description: You don't often see this.
fullText:
Chiefs set to do something cool for fans this offseason originally appeared on The Sporting News. Add The Sporting News as a Preferred Source by clicking here.

The Kansas City Chiefs are in the full swing of their offseason preparations as Andy Reid and his staff figure out a plan of attack.

But sometimes, certain parts of the offseason have nothing to do with football and the roster.

Sometimes it's about doing something out of the ordinary.

And now here comes something a little different from the Chiefs, and it isn't something I've seen or heard of.

Per Jonathan Jones of NFL on CBS, the Chiefs will be selling off items that the franchise no longer needs to fans.

Love when teams do this: the Chiefs will host a 1-day equipment sale this Saturday from 9 am until they run out. The sale will feature new and used player-worn items ‚Äì such as cleats, footballs, sweatshirts, T-shirts and more. Fans can begin lining up at 7 am.

‚Äî Jonathan Jones (@jjones9) February 19, 2026

More:¬†ESPN reveals stunning cost to fix glaring Ravens issue

With the glaring needs on the roster, general manager Brett Veach will have his work cut out.

Running back, offensive line, and pass rusher are the top three items on Reid's wishlist to be fixed, and the Chiefs, we think, as they always do, will find a way.

With Patrick Mahomes coming back from an ACL injury, it isn't known how healthy he'll be to begin the season. In fact, some think that around Week 6 could be a more realistic timeline.

Either way, the Chiefs have to solve their roster issues, but in the meantime, they are giving their fans the chance to buy some pretty cool items that will no doubt have a lot of value attached to them.

title: NFL star Rashee Rice accused of assaulting pregnant girlfriend
description: Kansas City Chiefs wide receiver Rashee Rice has been accused of repeatedly assaulting his former girlfriend while she was pregnant, in a civil lawsuit filed this week.The Kansas City Chiefs did not respond to AFP request for comment.
fullText:
Kansas City Chiefs wide receiver Rashee Rice has been accused of repeatedly assaulting his former girlfriend while she was pregnant, in a civil lawsuit filed this week.

Ex-girlfriend Dacoda Jones on Monday sued Rice for alleged assaults over a span of 18 months between 2023 and 2025, seeking more than $1 million in damages for "severe and permanent injuries."

"Rice has grabbed, choked, strangled, pushed, thrown, scratched, hit, and headbutted Ms. Jones, as well as hit her with inanimate objects," the lawsuit says.

"Additionally, he has engaged in other violent and abusive behaviors towards Ms. Jones, including throwing objects, destroying property, punching walls, and breaking furniture, as well as locking her out in the middle of the night.

"Many of these behaviors occurred while Ms. Jones was pregnant."

Jones had previously posted photos of herself with a bloodied lip, scratches and bruises in a now-deleted Instagram post, which did not name her alleged attacker.

In a statement to ESPN on Wednesday, Rice's lawyer Sean Lindsey said Jones had previously given a sworn statement that Rice had not struck her.

"We will allow the legal process to run its coursƒô and have no further comment at this time," said the attorney's statement.

An NFL spokesman told AFP "the matter remains under review." The Kansas City Chiefs did not respond to AFP request for comment.

Jones has two children with 25-year-old Rice, a talented pass-catcher who won a Super Bowl in 2024 at the end of his rookie year with the Chiefs.

In 2025, Rice served a six-game suspension after his conviction for causing a multi-vehicle¬†collision the previous year.

Rice pleaded guilty to felony charges of collision involving serious bodily injury and racing on a highway causing bodily injury.

title: What's next for Tyreek Hill after his release from the Dolphins? Keep an eye on Chiefs and Bills
description: Tyreek Hill is now a free agent for the first time in his career.
fullText:
Tyreek Hill is officially a free agent, putting him in an unfamiliar position for the first time in his career.

So, what‚Äôs next for the star wide receiver?

The Miami Dolphins officially released Hill on Monday, ending a four-season run in which the franchise bet big on him being a key piece to pair with quarterback Tua Tagovailoa. Ultimately, that didn‚Äôt work out. The Dolphins failed to win a single playoff game during his time in South Florida, continuing a drought that dates back to the 2000 season.

Hill went down with a devastating knee injury early this past season, too, including a dislocated knee. Hill‚Äôs agent said Monday that he‚Äôs ‚Äúprogressing well‚Äù in his rehab and will be ready to play at some point next season, and Hill vowed to return.

But who is in play for Hill next season? Yahoo Sports‚Äô ‚ÄúInside Coverage‚Äù podcast discussed a couple of possibilities Monday.

"He still has that speed. Even if he's 80% of what he was, he's still going to be one of the faster players in the NFL," Yahoo Sports senior betting analyst Ben Fawkes said. "So I think he can be a useful piece for a contender, but also at what price is the big question too."

The first landing spot is obvious. The Chiefs are the easiest match for Hill because his career began in Kansas City, and he won a Super Bowl ring there. He appeared to give a nod of approval on social media of the Chiefs' recent re-hiring of Eric Bieniemy as offensive coordinator.

But Hill‚Äôs usage in Kansas City may not be what he‚Äôs used to.

"Is [Hill] willing to accept a lesser role if that's what he is right now? Let's say the Chiefs, right? Well, is he their No. 1 [wideout]? No, that's probably Rasheed Rice, who has his own set of baggage,‚Äù Yahoo Sports NFL senior reporter Frank Schwab said. ‚ÄúAnd is he their speed guy? Well, no, that's probably Xavier Worthy. What role is he willing to accept? How much money is he willing to accept?"

There are, naturally, a lot of questions to be answered there. But Hill would be a solid weapon for the Chiefs, who just missed the playoffs for the first time in more than a decade.

Buffalo appears hellbent on doing just about anything possible to help lift quarterback Josh Allen over the postseason hump and to a Super Bowl. That included jettisoning a successful head coach in Sean McDermott in favor of offensive coordinator Joe Brady earlier this offseason.

Hill could be an easy add for a team needing an extra option. Khalil Shakir was their leading receiver last year with just 719 receiving yards, while tight ends Dalton Kincaid and Dawson Knox were second and third.

"They need that veteran piece," podcast host Andrew Siciliano. "They need that deep threat. They need a guy who down the field ‚Äî I'm sorry, Brandin Cooks ‚Äî can attack that football or just run away from the guy closest to him. So he doesn't have to have a contested catch there to win a playoff game in Denver."

The Chargers could be a great fit for Hill for multiple reasons. He‚Äôd get to pair up with Justin Herbert, who has statistically been a top tier quarterback during his first six seasons in the league even if the team has struggled at times. The Chargers have plenty of money to pay Hill, too, as they‚Äôre sitting with the third-most salary cap space in the league this offseason.

Oh, and Mike McDaniel is now the Chargers‚Äô offensive coordinator after he was fired by the Dolphins earlier this offseason. Reuniting with his former head coach on the other side of the country feels like it would make things even easier for Hill coming off of his injury.

Sure, the Patriots reached Super Bowl LX this past season. But something was missing, and that was very evident in the final game as the Seahawks cruised to the dominant win in the Bay Area.

Hill could easily step into New England and help young quarterback Drake Maye as he enters his third season in the league. Pairing Hill with fellow star Stefon Diggs, who racked up 1,013 receiving yards last season, and tight end Hunter Henry, might just be the boost the team needs to get over the hump.

Now this may not be Hill's first choice, considering the state of the Raiders in recent years. But there are plenty of reasons why it would work.

The Raiders are under new leadership once again this season with Klint Kubiak coming in as their head coach. The franchise has the No. 1 overall pick in the NFL Draft, too, which they will presumably use on Indiana quarterback and Heisman Trophy winner Fernando Mendoza. Getting Mendoza a veteran like Hill right away in his career, along with young running back Ashton Jeanty and tight end Brock Bowers, would be huge early on in his career.

Oh, and the Raiders have money to spend. That'd be nice for Hill, too.

title: Russell Wilson ranks Patrick Mahomes amongst other great quarterbacks
description: During a recent media appearance, Russell Wilson ranked Kansas City Chiefs Patrick Mahomes amongst other great quarterbacks
fullText:
The NFL offseason has many players taking time away from the field to address lingering injuries, decisions, and their playing future. The Kansas City Chiefs missed the playoffs in 2025 but are still a topic of conversation off the field, especially starting quarterback Patrick Mahomes.

During a recent episode of 'Hot Ones Versus,' Grammy-winning artist Ciara and Super Bowl champion Russell Wilson faced off with questions and wing challenges. The rules are simple: tell the truth, or suffer the wrath of the 'Last Dab'. Whoever eats the most wings loses, and Wilson answered a tough question regarding four quarterbacks, including himself.

Wilson ranked Mahomes second to Tom Brady, with himself third, ahead of Pro Football Hall of Famer Peyton Manning. The former Seattle Seahawks quarterback defeated Manning's Denver Broncos in Super Bowl XLVIII. He notably chose a spicy wing rather than answering his wife's question about the worst coach he's played for in his career.

The 37-year-old's 2025 season came to an end early with the New York Giants as he was benched after the Chiefs defeated him in Week 3. Wilson lost his starting job to rookie Jaxson Dart and, for the rest of the year, served primarily as a veteran mentor. In three games started (six played), he tossed three touchdowns and three interceptions for 831 yards.

Wilson has been rumored recently to be a potential backup option for the Chiefs in free agency.

This article originally appeared on Chiefs Wire: Russell Wilson ranks Patrick Mahomes amongst other great quarterbacks

title: Chiefs big winners of free agency with 1 key move
description: This would be an ideal move for the Chiefs.
fullText:
Chiefs big winners of free agency with 1 key move originally appeared on The Sporting News. Add The Sporting News as a Preferred Source by clicking here.

After a disastrous 2025 season, most know where the Kansas City Chiefs' free agency shopping needs to start.

Kareem Hunt and Isiah Pacheco are free agents, and it's unclear whether either will return in 2026; even if one does, the Chiefs need a significant upgrade.

But who? The franchise tried to trade for Breece Hall before the trade deadline, but that fell through. Now, though, there's a host of options for Breet Veach to look at.

And ESPN's Eric Moody is tipping the Chiefs will raid fellow AFC contender, the Jacksonville Jaguars, for star back Travis Etienne.

"Running back Travis Etienne Jr. will sign with the Chiefs during free agency," Moody wrote. "Etienne would be intriguing as a proven, versatile back who has surpassed 1,000 rushing yards in three of his four healthy seasons, including 1,107 yards and seven touchdowns in 2025.

"His ability to contribute as both a runner and receiver (5,136 career all-purpose yards with 32 touchdowns) would boost a Chiefs backfield that averaged less 4.0 yards per carry last season and failed to produce a running back with at least 200 receiving yards."

More:Ravens' Lamar Jackson tipped to join illustrious Hall of Fame group in 2026

Travis has all of the attributes that neither Hunt nor Pacheco has.

The pace, speed, burst, and home run ability. Not to mention his effectiveness as a receiver, either, which will add another element to Kansas City's passing game with Patrick Mahomes back.

Kansas City needs someone to take the offensive load off of Patrick's shoulders, and one way to do it is with a run game, and Etienne as the lead back could give the Chiefs their fear factor back.

Of course, money will be key here, but if the Chiefs are serious about turning this ship around in 2026, money will be no object, and if Etienne is available, they'll go get him.

title: Chiefs TE Travis Kelce recalls preseason matchup vs. Seahawks
description: During the recent episode of New Heights, Kansas City Chiefs tight end Travis Kelce recalled preseason matchup vs. the Seattle Seahawks | @EdEastonJr
fullText:
During the recent episode of the New Heights podcast, Kansas City Chiefs tight end Travis Kelce shared his thoughts on the Seattle Seahawks with wide receiver Cooper Kupp heading into Super Bowl LX against the New England Patriots. He reflected on the Seahawks' preseason victory over the Chiefs.

"You could feel the energy in the f---ing preseason, Coop (Cooper Kupp), I remember playing you guys in the preseason, and I was sitting there on the sideline, that second half, watching my guys try and battle your guys" said Kelce, "Kind of like second- and third-string guys, and I'm just like, 'This team has the f****** juice.' These guys love playing the game of football, and they do it together. And it wasn't just the starters; it was the guys after that. It was all the way through the end of the game, man."

Kelce and the Chiefs' starters were mostly spectators in Seattle that day as the Seahawks won convincingly.

"When you see guys loving to play the game together, like having that energy, having that excitement, it's the start of it," said Kelce, "And then from there, you obviously have great coaches, great leaders."

The Chiefs will be spectators on Super Bowl Sunday for the first time in years.

This article originally appeared on Chiefs Wire: Chiefs TE Travis Kelce recalls preseason matchup vs. Seahawks

title: Former linebacker on Chiefs‚Äô Super Bowl LIV team charged with girlfriend‚Äôs murder
description: Former Chiefs linebacker who was on the 2019 championship team was charged with murder in Tennessee.
fullText:
Darron Lee, a former Chiefs linebacker, has been charged with the murder of his girlfriend, according to Tennessee authorities.

The Hamilton County Sheriff‚Äôs Office said deputies arrived Thursday at a residence in Ooltewah, Tennessee and found a female victim. After attempting CPR, it was determined she was deceased.

‚ÄúDue to the condition of the victim and the residence, HCSO Criminal Investigative Services Detectives responded. Preliminary findings indicate the victim‚Äôs death was the result of a homicide,‚Äù the sheriff‚Äôs office said in a statement.

‚ÄúThe victim‚Äôs boyfriend, Darron Lee, was identified as the suspect and taken into custody at the scene.‚Äù

Lee, who played for the Chiefs in 2019, has been charged with first-degree murder and tampering with evidence. Lee was in 16 games that season, but he didn‚Äôt appear in the playoffs as the Chiefs won Super Bowl LIV.

According to WRCB-TV in Chattanooga, ‚ÄúLee told (first responders) that he had found her unconscious on the couch, and thought that she had perhaps fallen in the shower, but his statements didn‚Äôt line up with the ‚Äòconcerning conditions‚Äô within the home, the arrest report says.

‚ÄúDeputies with the Hamilton County Sheriff‚Äôs Office say they found blood spatter on the walls and flooring in multiple locations, as well as broken glass scattered across the kitchen area. They also observed cleaning materials in ‚Äòabnormal places.‚Äô‚Äù

The WRCB story said a medical examiner found the victim had a stab wound to the abdomen as well as a bruise on her head and other injuries.

The New York Post reported Lee is being held without bond and has a court date set for Wednesday.

title: Chiefs TE Travis Kelce receives praise from a popular comedian
description: Kansas City Chiefs tight end Travis Kelce receives praise from comedian Ron Funches | @EdEastonJr
fullText:
The questions surrounding Kansas City Chiefs tight end Travis Kelce's future continue to dominate the team's offseason headlines. He has established a growing career in entertainment, catching the attention of many in the business.

During a recent podcast co-hosted by ESPN's Mina Kimes and David Dennis Jr., which discussed entertainment and pop culture, they sat down with comedian and Traitors reality-show contestant Ron Funches. He discussed working on the show alongside Donna Kelce and first meeting Travis while he was hosting the game show "Are You Smarter Than a Celebrity".

Funches, who served as one of the celebrity panelists on the show, offered high praise for the eleven-time Pro Bowler.

"An amazing game show host," said Funches. "Never met this man in my life, and was honestly like, 'All right, football guy, you gonna come in here and host this show? The thing that I want to do? I want to host this show. Let me see what you got,"

The 2024 show showcased another engaging side of Kelce, underscoring his readiness for the bright lights of the entertainment industry.

"I'm like, damn, this man (is) charming as hell. I get it, this is why you, (are) marrying a billionaire. "He is so charming and so sweet and so kind," said Funches, who followed with a Travis game invite story months after the show wrapped, "I was just in Kansas City on the road. Didn't mention it to him, didn't bring it up. He sends me a DM, like, 'Hey, if you and your friends, whoever you got on the road with you, you want to come to the Chiefs game? The box is gonna be full because Taylor's gonna be there. But I got tickets for you.'"

Funches formed a bond with Donna on the show, only to be eliminated after a few episodes.

This article originally appeared on Chiefs Wire: Chiefs TE Travis Kelce receives praise from a popular comedian

title: Bills News: Josh Allen Says Locker Room ‚ÄòDidn‚Äôt Really Care‚Äô About Chiefs Missing the Playoffs
description: The Kansas City Chiefs have always been the biggest thorn in the Buffalo Bills‚Äô path when it comes to the Super Bowl. In fact, Josh Allen has lost four different contests against Patrick Mahomes in the playoffs over the years.
fullText:
The Kansas City Chiefs have always been the biggest thorn in the Buffalo Bills‚Äô path when it comes to the Super Bowl. In fact, Josh Allen has lost four different contests against Patrick Mahomes in the playoffs over the years. That‚Äôs why, when those same Chiefs missed the playoffs this year, it should have been good news for the Bills‚Äô locker room. Except it wasn‚Äôt.

According to Allen, the team never focused on the Chiefs‚Äô exclusion from the playoffs. It went against what many football fans were thinking at the time when Buffalo reached the postseason with a dominant run no less. Many believed that the absence of Mahomes was another significant advantage for the team.

‚ÄúThat‚Äôs something that we don‚Äôt talk about in the locker room, really. We don‚Äôt really care so much about who else is in the playoffs with us, how to get there, or how to get it done. The short answer is we didn‚Äôt get it done this year. And that‚Äôs on us, that‚Äôs on me,‚Äù Allen saidduring his appearance on First Things First.

It‚Äôs surprising to hear, to say the least. After all, Allen has lost to Mahomes by one score in the playoffs three times. Last season, less than one yard decided the outcome of the game.

Later on, Allen shed some light on his mentality going into this postseason.

‚ÄúWe‚Äôre going to keep working tirelessly until we find a way to get there and get it done. I understand the people‚Äôs thoughts of you don‚Äôt have no Mahomes, no Lamar, no Joe Burrow in the playoffs. But there‚Äôs some dang good teams in this playoffs. They‚Äôre not there just by chance. They‚Äôre there for a reason. And the two teams that are in the Super Bowl, they deserve to be there,‚Äù Allen stated.

Some may see it as an excuse from the former MVP, but Allen is right. There were a few teams better than the Chiefs in the AFC this season. Even the Jacksonville Jaguars went on a run, giving the Bills a tough test in the Wild Card round.

The Denver Broncos ultimately ended up being the team to send Allen home this time around. They had an elite defense and were playing with home-field advantage. Allen turned the ball over four times in that game, including a pivotal overtime interception. It went down as another heartbreaking playoff loss in Bills history.

Maybe one of these years, Allen and the Bills will get over the hump. At this point in his career, a Super Bowl win is a massive monkey the QB can‚Äôt seem to get off his back. It does, however, sound like he will always stay motivated to win one because of his love for the game. Still, the lack of a Lombardi Trophy in his hands must be starting to wear on him.

The post Bills News: Josh Allen Says Locker Room ‚ÄòDidn‚Äôt Really Care‚Äô About Chiefs Missing the Playoffs appeared first on The SportsRush.

title: Kansas City Chiefs News: Team ‚ÄòExpected‚Äô to Move on From Key Starter
description: The Kansas City Chiefs missed the playoffs this past season, finishing with a 6-11 record‚Äîthe first time that has happened [‚Ä¶]
fullText:
The Kansas City Chiefs missed the playoffs this past season, finishing with a 6-11 record‚Äîthe first time that has happened since 2014. Coming off their first six-win campaign since 2012, some big changes are expected from Kansas City this offseason.

Nate Taylor of ESPN wrote that the Chiefs are ‚Äúexpected‚Äù to move on from Isiah Pacheco this offseason and bring in a new starting running back. After being hired as offensive coordinator, Eric Bieniemy ‚Äúwill be tasked with putting together the correct run-blocking scheme‚Äù for the club.

It is a relatively easy decision for the Chiefs coaching staff and front office to make. Kansas City finished the regular season ranked 20th in yards per carry average (4.2) and 25th in rushing (106.6 yards per game). Furthermore, both NFL free agency and the 2026 NFL Draft are deep at running back.

On the open market, Breece Hall, Kenneth Walker III, Travis Etienne Jr., and Javonte Williams will be available as quality starters. If the organization prefers to find a rotational back to pair with a rookie, it could sign someone like Rachaad White, Rico Dowdle, or Kenneth Gainwell.

Some have theorized that the Chiefs could use their first-round pick on All-American running back Jeremiyah Love. He is an All-Pro caliber talent who some believe is one of the top running back prospects to enter the NFL since Saquon Barkley. However, it is unlikely that general manager Brett Veach would use the ninth-overall pick on a running back.

More likely, Kansas City will sign one of the top veteran running backs in free agency and then use a mid-round pick on another ball carrier. While it might not offer as much upside as drafting Love, it could still be a very effective way to improve the Chiefs‚Äô rushing attack.

title: 2026 NFL Draft: 5 Senior Bowl defensive linemen Chiefs fans must watch
description: Kansas City Chiefs fans need to check out some of the best defensive linemen from the Senior Bowl before the 2026 NFL Draft.
fullText:
The Kansas City Chiefs need to add depth, and maybe even a starter, along their defensive line in the 2026 NFL Draft. Fortunately, some of the best trench players in the class recently came together to compete in Mobile, Ala. for the Senior Bowl. Several prospects stood out as potential targets for the Chiefs.

According to Pro Football Focus, George Karlaftis was the only Kansas City edge rusher to amass 35 or more pressures in 2025. For reference, 59 edge rushers across the entire NFL reached that threshold. Within the AFC West, a duo of Denver Broncos, three Las Vegas Raiders and three Los Angeles Chargers accomplished the feat. Only the Chiefs lagged behind.

Future Pro Football Hall of Fame defensive tackle Chris Jones helps the Chiefs keep their noses above water in the pass rush, but he offers limited value in run defense at this stage of his career. Jones turns 32 years old before the start of the 2026 season.

The Chiefs need to add immediate production on the edge while also considering the long-term future of their interior defensive line. The Senior Bowl features enough star prospects to satisfy both needs, if the Chiefs hit on their selections.

When the 2026 Panini Senior Bowl kicks off at 1:30 p.m. CT today on NFL Network, Chiefs fans should keep an eye out for these five star defensive linemen.

Height is undersized at 6‚Äô2 3/8‚Äù, 234 lbs. with 32 3/4‚Äù arms. Those measurements didn‚Äôt stop him from dominating opposing offensive tackles during the team periods. He beat Dametrious Crownover with an outside jab into a B-gap swim and reached the quarterback in just 2.1 seconds on Wednesday. Height‚Äôs speed rush is very effective and sets up his twitchy inside counters.

Height suffered several clean losses. He struggles to win when offensive tackles get into his pads early in the play, and his limited mass makes it difficult to survive heavy punches. Height projects best as a rotational edge rusher who could develop into a full-time starter, similar to Alex Highsmith‚Äôs path on the Steelers.

Jacas, Kyle Louis and Zion Young stood at the pinnacle of performance throughout the Senior Bowl practices. At 6‚Äô3 1/8‚Äù, 260 lbs. with 32 3/4‚Äù arms, Jacas is a stout, sawed-off rusher capable of driving through the offensive tackle‚Äôs frame with power, winning around the corner with technical savvy or reducing inside to challenge guards.

Jacas won at the Senior Bowl with an outside speed rush, speed-to-power conversion, chop-rip combinations and swims through the B-gap. His explosiveness off the line of scrimmage led to several instantaneous wins.

Jacas fits the archetype of edge rusher Kansas City values. He entered the week with mixed grades. Now, it seems inconceivable that he goes anywhere later than the early third round.

Banks missed most of his final season with injuries and started off on the wrong foot in Mobile. His first day or practice was a wash, but he dominated across the final two sessions. At 6‚Äô6‚Äù, 335 lbs. with 35‚Äù arms and 10 3/4‚Äù hands, Banks is a behemoth capable of pushing the pocket or applying clean pressure by discarding guards with his violent hands.

Caleb Banks gets a win on Auburn‚Äôs Jeremiah Wright, and he‚Äôs feeling pretty good about it. #thedraftstartsinmobile #seniorbowl #nfldraft pic.twitter.com/qIbxVFIQXi

‚Äî Sam Teets (@Sam_Teets33) January 29, 2026

Banks displays rare foot quickness and agility early in plays, especially for a defender his size. His pad level becomes a limiting factor late in games, but the tradeoff seems worth it for teams hoping to add more muscle to their defensive front.

Hunter is a physical freak in his own right. He‚Äôs 6‚Äô3 1/2‚Äù, 320 lbs. with 34 1/4‚Äù arms. His rare explosiveness helps him drive vertically on pass plays, but he also possesses the quickness and lateral agility to exchange gaps or sidestep and play around blockers.

Lee Hunter is a top 50 player for me. 330-lb NT with heavy hands and a very quick first step for his size. Comfortably the most detailed and instinctive pass rusher in the '26 NT class pic.twitter.com/NC3o1WNdu9

‚Äî James Foster (@NoFlagsFilm) December 10, 2025

Hunter‚Äôs stout anchor and long arms make it easy for him to stack, peek and shed blockers in the run game. Displacing him at the point of attack is a challenging task. Hunter resets the line of scrimmage by driving blockers into the backfield and finishes big plays with his closing burst.

Hunter‚Äôs skill set and playstyle make him the perfect complement to Chris Jones. The Texas Tech product should rank near the top of Kansas City‚Äôs draft board.

Young ranked among the top performers at the Senior Bowl. He is a dense and powerful edge rusher at 6‚Äô5 1/4‚Äù, 262 lbs. with 33 1/2‚Äù arms. Throughout the week, he displayed the power to push the pocket and soften angles before finishing his rushes with counters.

The power that Missouri‚Äôs Zion Young has shown at the Senior Bowl is terrifying. You don‚Äôt want to see him lining up across from you in a four-point stance with those bent elbows. pic.twitter.com/qCksPcbCZh

‚Äî Bobby Football (@Rob__Paul) January 29, 2026

Young sent Jude Bowry tumbling in a one-on-one rep and folded J.C. Davis in one of the most dominant displays of power all week. Young primarily relies on winning through the offensive lineman‚Äôs frame or countering into or prying open the B-gap because of his lack of bend. However, his long strides help him push upfield quickly and led to some clean wins in the team periods.

Young‚Äôs arm length, play strength and anchor also make him an effective edge-setter in the run game.

This article originally appeared on Chiefs Wire: Chiefs NFL Draft: Watch these 5 Senior Bowl defensive linemen

title: Kayla Nicole gets swarmed by Swifties for 'liking' Travis Kelce post
description: The influencer dated the Kansas City Chiefs breakout star before he got engaged to Taylor Swift.
fullText:
Kayla Nicole gets swarmed by Swifties for 'liking' Travis Kelce post originally appeared on The Sporting News. Add The Sporting News as a Preferred Source by clicking here.

Kayla Nicole found herself back in the middle of online discourse this week after a seemingly minor social media interaction sparked major reaction from fans.

The former girlfriend of Travis Kelce was flooded with criticism after screenshots circulated showing she had liked a recent Instagram post involving the Kansas City Chiefs star. The post, shared by Bleacher Report, highlighted Travis and his brother Jason Kelce helping fund U.S. hockey player Laila Edwards‚Äô family trip to Milan for her Winter Olympics debut.

MORE:¬†Cardi B will be the musical guest on 'SNL'

The caption praised the Kelce brothers‚Äô generosity, calling them ‚Äútwo great guys that went out of their way when they didn‚Äôt have to.‚Äù While the story itself focused on the charitable gesture, attention quickly shifted to Nicole after users noticed her verified account had interacted with the post.

That single ‚Äúlike‚Äù was enough to set off a wave of backlash, particularly from fans protective of Travis‚Äô current relationship with Taylor Swift. Screenshots of the interaction spread rapidly across platforms, and commentary soon followed. One user accused Nicole of chasing attention, writing that she ‚Äúreally dislikes not being talked about.‚Äù Another questioned why the moment was being amplified at all, arguing that continued focus only fuels unnecessary drama.

The reaction added to a growing list of moments that have kept Nicole in headlines since her 2022 breakup with Travis. Last year, fans speculated about possible shade when she recreated Toni Braxton‚Äôs ‚ÄúHe Wasn‚Äôt Man Enough‚Äù look from the early 2000s music video, and other posts have also been interpreted ‚Äî fairly or not ‚Äî as indirect jabs at Swift.

While Nicole has not publicly addressed the latest situation, the renewed attention arrives as the Kelce family continues to dominate headlines for entirely different reasons.

MORE:¬†Austin Reaves' YoungLA fashion drop gets love from Luka Doncic and Lebron James

Travis‚Äô mother, Donna Kelce, recently raised eyebrows during promotional interviews ahead of her appearance on The Traitors. When asked who she hoped to avoid encountering on the show, Donna listed rivals, coaches, and then added one more category.

‚ÄúMaybe some of my sons‚Äô adversaries,‚Äù she said. ‚ÄúThat could either be on other teams, or it could be coaches, or it could be past girlfriends.‚Äù

title: Chiefs DL George Karlaftis wins 2025 Ed Block Courage Award
description: Kansas City Chiefs defensive lineman George Karlaftis wins 2025 Ed Block Courage Award | @EdEastonJr
fullText:
The Kansas City Chefs have announced their special team awards for the 2025 season. George Karlaftis wins the 2025 Ed Block Courage Award, showing grit and bravery well beyond the football field.

The Ed Block Courage Award is annually presented to one member of each team and recognizes a player who exemplifies commitment to the principles of sportsmanship and courage.

"I know one thing about this team that whoever is going to get the opportunity is going to step up and make the most out of it," said Karlaftis to reporters before Week 16, helping to inspire his teammates, "There's guys that haven't seen the field all year that are hungry. Guys that want to prove what they're made of and all that stuff. Whoever's out there, that's what coach said, whoever's out there is going to play to the best of their abilities and finish this thing out strong."

Congrats on winning the Ed Block Courage Award, @TheGK3! pic.twitter.com/7HmMn6AAQP

‚Äî Kansas City Chiefs (@Chiefs) January 24, 2026

Karlaftis finished last season with 48 total tackles and six sacks in 16 games. He also had a fumble recovery with two pass deflections.

All of the team awards were voted on by the players themselves, reflecting the locker room's true feelings about the starting defensive end.

title: Should Chiefs swing big at free agent RB?
description: If the Chiefs are going to swing, swing big.
fullText:
Should Chiefs swing big at free agent RB? originally appeared on The Sporting News. Add The Sporting News as a Preferred Source by clicking here.

There is no denying that the Kansas City Chiefs had a poor run game in 2025, with Isiah Pacheco and Kareem Hunt.

The Chiefs managed just 106.6 yards per game, ranking them 24th in the NFL. That isn't good. The problem was that there wasn't a home-run threat from Pacheco or Hunt. Both are plodders and bruising backs.

That has to change in 2026. The Chiefs need a lightning rod out of the backfield. You could get one in the draft, with Jeremiyah Love, but what about free agency?

The Chiefs tried to get Breece Hall midway through last season, but failed.

So, could they go back to the free agent well? Absolutely, but in my mind, they've got to go big.

Why not attempt to get Seattle Seahawks running back Kenneth Walker, who is the No. 1 free agent back according to PFF?

More:Chiefs fix problematic issue for Patrick Mahomes in latest mock draft

A do-it-all back for the Seahawks, what Walker could do in Kansas City's backfield is a tantalizing thought.

The only problem is with his playoff performances; he's driving up his price, and if he wins the Super Bowl? Yeah, a huge contract is likely forthcoming.

The Chiefs likely won't want to get into a bidding war for Walker's services. Of course, it depends on how much they would want it, if at all.

But Kansas City needs an overhaul at running back, and having Walker behind Patrick Mahomes would be something that gets Chiefs Kingdom excited.

fullText:

Kansas City Chiefs tight end Travis Kelce has a decision to make regarding his future.

So there‚Äôs no doubt in my mind that he can still play. We‚Äôre trying to be respectful and let him have the time that he needs to make a decision.

title: At Davos, tech CEOs laid out their vision for AI‚Äôs world domination
description:
Tech chiefs waxed poetic about AI to delegates at Davos. Plus, the ‚Äòhuman‚Äô drama of AI startups and why Tesla is thriving in Texas
Hello, and welcome to TechScape. This week‚Äôs edition is a team effort: my colleague Heather Stewart reports on the plans for AI‚Äôs world domination at Davos; I examine how huge investments have followed AI companies with little to their names but drama and dreams; and Nick Robins-Early spotlights how lax regulation of autonomous driving in Texas allowed Tesla to thrive.
 Continue reading...
fullText:
Tech chiefs waxed poetic about AI to delegates at Davos. Plus, the ‚Äòhuman‚Äô drama of AI startups and why Tesla is thriving in Texas

Hello, and welcome to TechScape. This week‚Äôs edition is a team effort: my colleague Heather Stewart reports on the plans for AI‚Äôs world domination at Davos; I examine how huge investments have followed AI companies with little to their names but drama and dreams; and Nick Robins-Early spotlights how lax regulation of autonomous driving in Texas allowed Tesla to thrive.

When they weren‚Äôt discussing Donald Trump, delegates at the World Economic Forum last week were being dazzled by the prospects for artificial intelligence.

Up and down the main street of the Swiss Alps town, almost every shopfront was temporarily emblazoned with the neon slogan of a tech firm ‚Äì or a consultancy promising to tell executives how to incorporate AI into their business. Cloudflare‚Äôs wood-panelled HQ urged delegates to ‚Äúconnect, protect and build together‚Äù, and Wipro‚Äôs shouted: ‚ÄúDream Solve Prove Repeat.‚Äù

At the conference, tech CEOs laid out their hopes for how the physical manifestations of AI will blanket the world in the coming years. Microsoft chief executive Satya Nadella told a rapt audience about how ‚Äútoken factories‚Äù, as he calls datacenters, will have to be distributed across the world, to diffuse the benefits of AI globally.

‚ÄúTo me, a long term, scalable solution is to have all of these token factories part of the real economy connected to the grid, connected to the telco network ‚Äì and that‚Äôs what will drive that scale, whether it‚Äôs in the global south, or in the developed world,‚Äù Nadella said.

Meanwhile Google was showing off the latest iteration of its Google Glasses to excited delegates; and there were endless sessions in the Davos congress centre about the technology‚Äôs potential benefits ‚Äì including a breathless chat with late addition to the schedule Elon Musk, though with the SpaceX IPO apparently looming, he was keenest to talk about going to Mars.

Away from the glitzy shopfronts, though, there was significant concern being expressed that all this proves to be an epic bubble.

In an interview with the Financial Times, DeepMind chief Demis Hassabis warned that some aspects of AI investment do look, ‚Äúbubble-like‚Äù, but insisted that, ‚Äúif the bubble bursts, we [ie Google, not society at large] will be fine‚Äù.

Nadella offered one test for how we would know if it is a bubble ‚Äì which I didn‚Äôt find reassuring. ‚ÄúA tell-tale sign of this as a bubble, is if all we‚Äôre talking about are the tech firms,‚Äù he said.

Much of Silicon Valley has been captivated over the past week by a ‚Äúvery human drama‚Äù, as the Wall Street Journal put it. Thinking Machines Lab, a startup founded by former OpenAI chief technology officer Mira Murati, fired her own chief technology officer, Barret Zoph, over a relationship with a colleague and a recent lack of productivity, per the Journal. Within hours, her ex-employee ‚Äì along with one of her co-founders and a third employee ‚Äì had reportedly signed offers with OpenAI, which they left just last year to join her startup. The three had told her they disagreed with the direction of the company in the meeting that ended with Zoph‚Äôs firing, according to the Journal. For his part, Zoph told the Journal that Murati had fired him simply for telling her he was considering another job.

As dishy as the drama might be, the stakes of Murati‚Äôs mess differ from a juicy celebrity entanglement that might be chronicled in TMZ or Page Six, two of my favorite publications. The stakes in San Francisco are billions of real dollars and more than $10bn potential ones. Murati‚Äôs company has raised $2bn in venture capital since its founding in February 2025. It is valued at $12bn. The talent involved in these California productions ‚Äì not movies but rather AI tools used by hundreds of millions of people ‚Äì takes on superstar significance.

Thinking Machines has released one product, Tinker, in October 2025, meant to streamline the customization of large language models, a rather niche concern in comparison with ChatGPT‚Äôs ambitions to replace Google search or Claude‚Äôs coding aptitude.

The massive investment and resulting valuation are chasing little in terms of real offerings from the company. A new company profiled in the New York Times last week, Humans&, has naught but a dream, an ugly website ‚Äì and several hundred million dollars. Researchers from Google, Anthropic, and Elon Musk‚Äôs xAI, including one who helped develop the notorious Grok AI tool, founded the company just three months ago. They aim to facilitate collaboration between humans and machines rather than separation ‚Äì ‚Äúinnovations in long-horizon and multi-agent reinforcement learning, memory, and user understanding‚Äù, per the site. If that sounds gauzy, it is because the company has not launched a product.

Humans& has raised $480m from Nvidia, Jeff Bezos, and Google, per the New York Times. It is valued at $4.48bn. It has ‚Äì say it with me one more time ‚Äì not launched a product.

Whatever fears of an AI bubble may be circulating, the money is still flowing, chasing after the future with an enormous but uncertain bet in the present.

Elon Musk announced last week that Tesla had removed human safety monitors from its Robotaxis in Austin, Texas, as the company moves to expand its autonomous vehicle business. As with most things Musk, the reality was a bit more complicated ‚Äì Tesla‚Äôs vice-president of software later clarified on X that the company had deployed ‚Äúa few unsupervised vehicles mixed in with the broader robotaxi fleet with safety monitors‚Äù.

What Tesla‚Äôs test-run of fully driverless vehicles did highlight, however, was the difference between how much leeway Texas gives autonomous vehicles compared with California, the birthplace of autonomous driving in the US and the home of the highest number of self-driving cars in the country. The Texas department of motor vehicles does not have regulatory authority over autonomous vehicles in the state, instead autonomous vehicles are governed by the state‚Äôs transportation code. Although a new government authorization system for autonomous vehicles is set to be implemented in the coming months, there‚Äôs currently no application process required for autonomous vehicle operators in the state. 

 ‚ÄúAutonomous vehicles on Texas roads are subject to all traffic laws and can be cited for safety violations, but do not yet require specific authorization to operate,‚Äù the Texas DMV said.

Also surprising is the state‚Äôs lack of regulations on operating an autonomous vehicle if it‚Äôs for personal, non-commercial use. As long as it complies with some stipulations, such as traffic laws and safety standards, an autonomous vehicle can drive around Texas without anyone in the car.

 ‚ÄúAny motor vehicle equipped with an automated driving system may operate in this state,‚Äù the Texas transportation code states. ‚ÄúAn automated motor vehicle may operate in this state with the automated driving system engaged, regardless of whether a human driver is physically present in the automated motor vehicle.‚Äù

Meanwhile in California, the state‚Äôs department of motor vehicles requires three stages of testing and permitting for commercial autonomous vehicles. Regulators are also in the process of considering new rules that could add even more requirements on vehicle operators. Tesla caused confusion last October when Musk announced a ride-hailing service in the Bay Area, only for regulators to say that the company did not have authorization to operate paid or unpaid autonomous rides to the public. On the Robotaxi section of Tesla‚Äôs website, it only mentions Texas.

title: Chiefs‚Äô Andy Reid is ‚Äòfired up‚Äô about new staff: ‚ÄòChange can be good‚Äô
description: Kansas City‚Äôs head coach is optimistic about the coaching shakeup.
fullText:
For the first time in eight years, the Kansas City Chiefs were not involved in Sunday‚Äôs NFL doubleheader of conference championships. Head coach Andy Reid has been a staple of both the AFC and NFC title games throughout his career, so with his 2025 team unable to even make the postseason, a change around him was not a surprising result.

The offensive coordinator spot has officially been turned over to Eric Bienemy, despite former coordinator Matt Nagy still searching for his next job. In total, five positions on the offensive coaching staff have been vacated since the end of last season. So far, the only official hire is Bienemy, but Reid made it clear he‚Äôs excited about the new chapter during a Zoom call with local media on Monday.

Andy's got great energy in this presser. Good to see him so lively. He's ready to get back to work

‚Äî Ron Kopp Jr (@RonOnChiefs) January 26, 2026

After a few spirited answers, Reid was asked about the noticeable energy in his words.

‚ÄúI‚Äôm fired up to get in this offseason and get going,‚Äù Reid responded. ‚ÄúWe didn‚Äôt do very well this past year, and that has not been our MO here. So I want to fix the problems we had in all phases. There will be people that move on, people that come in‚Ä¶ change can be good sometimes for you, so that‚Äôs what I‚Äôm fired up about.‚Äù

Some will point at Bieniemy‚Äôs history with Reid and Kansas City as hardly a ‚Äúchange,‚Äù but his style is objectively different than Nagy‚Äôs. Reid acknowledged that and emphasized how Bieniemy straightforwardly communicates with players and coaches, including star quarterback Patrick Mahomes.

‚ÄúI‚Äôd tell you EB will be very direct with him,‚Äù Reid shared. ‚Äú[Mahomes] knows it‚Äôs coming from a place of knowledge there.‚Äù

Still, there will be criticism that the change needed was in reference to his offensive scheme. Reid would agree that it needs a refresh ‚Äî or a retooling, as he foreshadowed in December ‚Äî so that‚Äôs what he hopes the newest hires help with.

‚ÄúEverywhere you go in this business, you pick something up,‚Äù Reid explained. ‚ÄúYou might take it with you, or you might say, ‚ÄòI don‚Äôt want to do that.‚Äò‚Äù

‚ÄúI welcome that, I always keep my ears and eyes open for things,‚Äù Reid assured. ‚ÄúThat‚Äôs why we‚Äôre very seldom stagnant, and why, even with our record, I felt I could stand in front of you guys and go ‚Äòlisten, what worked for us the year before, it just flipped on us.‚Äô That‚Äôs sometimes how this thing works, so now it‚Äôs making sure we get back and do the right things, correct some things, and then get them going in the right direction again.‚Äù

In the modern age of accessible information, Reid reminded those listening that new ideas can be introduced without further hiring. It just takes effort and willingness.

‚ÄúYou use all the technology that‚Äôs out there,‚Äù Reid pointed out. ‚ÄúThere is no reason to be stagnant; you have too many different options, you shouldn‚Äôt have to bring in the latest, greatest here and there, all that. You have all that right at a finger tip for you, if you go that route.‚Äù

There will likely be little change in the chain of command for calling a play into Mahomes, but that‚Äôs because it is already a collaborative process. The positive change will simply be the new voices.

‚ÄúI still enjoy calling plays,‚Äù Reid admitted. ‚ÄúBut what I do, I‚Äôm also not afraid to delegate and get opinions from people. Even in certain situations, letting them go ahead and call things in different areas. We do this jointly. I keep it open, and I‚Äôve felt that‚Äôs the best way. I want guys to contribute, I want them to work hard and be experts in their area, and then accumulate in all areas. I‚Äôve always mixed and matched there, and it seemed to have been fairly productive.‚Äù

The change is welcomed by many in Kansas City. The head coach‚Äôs enthusiasm and upbeat energy when talking about the transition prove that it is already reinvigorating the people it needs to.

title: Chiefs DE Ashton Gillotte wins Mack Lee Hill Rookie of the Year Award
description: Kansas City Chiefs defensive end Ashton Gillotte wins 2025 Mack Lee Hill Rookie of the Year Award | @EdEastonJr
fullText:
The Kansas City Chefs have announced their special team awards for the 2025 season. Ashton Gillotte was awarded the 2025 Mack Lee Hill Rookie of the Year Award as the team's best rookie.

Named in remembrance of Mack Lee Hill, a former tailback for the Chiefs who tragically passed away during his second season with the team. The award is presented to Kansas City's top rookie or first-year player, and for 2025, Gillotte earned it for his standout performance.

"I think I'm better than where I started the year. It's obviously just comfortability thing, getting used to the level of play." said Gillotte to reporters before the Chiefs' Week 17 Christmas Day game, "Everyone's the top player in this league and you're going to get the best shot from everyone every week. Just being able to be more comfortable on the field (and) not think as much about plays and stuff, that's kind of what has helped me, and just continuing to build."

This rook made a statement this season! @AshtonGillotte pic.twitter.com/um3im3cWi3

‚Äî Kansas City Chiefs (@Chiefs) January 24, 2026

Gillotte was selected 66th overall in the 2025 NFL Draft, tallying 24 pressures, eight quarterback hits, three tackles-for-loss, and 1.5 sacks during the season. The 24 pressures, on 268 pass-rushing snaps, placed the former Louisville Cardinals star seventh among all rookie edge rushers.

All of the team awards were voted on by the players themselves, reflecting the locker room's true feelings about the rookie pass rusher.

This article originally appeared on Chiefs Wire: Chiefs DE Ashton Gillotte wins Mack Lee Hill Rookie of the Year Award

title: Chiefs QB Patrick Mahomes wins 2025 Derrick Thomas Team MVP Award
description: Kansas City Chiefs quarterback Patrick Mahomes wins 2025 Derrick Thomas Team MVP Award
fullText:
The Kansas City Chefs have announced their special team awards for the 2025 season. Patrick Mahomes was awarded the prestigious Derrick Thomas Team MVP Award for his efforts on and off the field to lead the team.

During a challenging season, Mahomes remained a constant professional, keeping optimism within the team.

"I mean, our ceiling is playing in the Super Bowl. We've got all the same guys, and we added players. But at the end of the day, you've got to go out and do it on a week-in, week-out basis," said Mahomes after the Week 13 loss to the Dallas Cowboys, "We can beat anybody, but we've shown that we can lose to anybody. So, we've got to be more consistent. It starts with me being consistent throughout the entire game, not in just big moments."

This year's team MVP goes to @PatrickMahomes! pic.twitter.com/1Biin6IJ7M

‚Äî Kansas City Chiefs (@Chiefs) January 24, 2026

Mahomes had another strong season with 4,009 total yards split between 3,587 passing and 422 rushing. He also contributed 27 total touchdowns, 22 passing, and 5 rushing. The two-time league MVP was named as an alternate for the 2026 Pro Bowl Games, although he wouldn't be available due to knee surgery.

All of these awards were voted on by the players themselves, reflecting the locker room's true feelings about their starting quarterback.

This article originally appeared on Chiefs Wire: Chiefs QB Patrick Mahomes wins 2025 Derrick Thomas Team MVP Award

title: Jessica Pegula reveals special motivation behind beating Madison Keys as defending Australian Open champion exits
description: Pegula, whose parents own the Buffalo Bills, avoided wearing a Kansas City Chiefs jersey as a forfeit after setting up a quarter-final with Amanda Anisimova
fullText:
Jessica Pegula avoided wearing a Kansas City Chiefs jersey as she defeated Madison Keys to end her fellow podcast host‚Äôs Australia Open title defence.

Pegula will play another American in fourth seed Amanda Anisimova in the quarter-finals after reaching the last-eight in Melbourne for the fourth time.

The 31-year-old sixth seed is good friends with Keys, who won her first grand slam title at the Australian Open last year, and they host The Player's Box podcast together along with Jennifer Brady and Desirae Krawczyk.

They recorded an episode before their fourth-round match, and decided the winner would choose a forfeit for the loser.

Keys decided that if she won, Pegula, whose parents own the NFL team the Buffalo Bills, would have had to wear a Chiefs jersey with Travis Kelce and Taylor Swift on the back.

In ensuring she avoided wearing the colours of the source of Buffalo‚Äôs recent post-season woes, Pegula will instead make Keys eat an apple pie topped with melted cheese.

‚ÄúI had a lot of motivation today,‚Äù Pegula said after her 6-3 6-4 victory over Keys, with the pair remaining in good spirits as they were seen chatting in the gym post-match as Pegula avoided the forfeit.

‚ÄúThat was bad," said Pegula. "She was, like, 'Mine's worse'. I was, like, 'What are you talking about? My family owns the Bills. This team has owned us in the post-season'.

‚ÄúAll she has to do is eat a piece of pie. What is the big deal? I think that was really some extra motivation, because that would have been a tough moment for me.‚Äù

Pegula said the apple pie topped with cheddar cheese was her family's Thanksgiving tradition.

"A bet is a bet, so I'll do it," said Keys. "I hope it's less gross than I think it's going to be, but we will find out, I guess."

Keys, meanwhile, is set to drop out of the world‚Äôs top 10 after her fourth-round exit but said she was proud of how she had handle the experience of returning as defending champion.

‚ÄúIt's obviously not the way that I wanted things to end here, but I'm still really proud of myself,‚Äù Keys said

‚ÄúI think coming back, being defending champion, dealing with all of the extra pressure and nerves, I'm just really proud of myself for how I handled it.

‚ÄúJust one of those days where I feel like Jess beat me, and I can kind of walk away with my head held high.‚Äù

Pegula is bidding to win her first grand slam title, having coming closest at the US Open with an appearance in the final and semi-finals in the last two seasons.

But she is yet to drop a set so far and will be confident when she meets another US Open runner-up in Anisimova, who is bidding to win her first grand slam title after defeats in the finals of Wimbledon and the US Open last season.

‚ÄúI'm just really happy that the work that I've done with my coaches,‚Äù Pegula said. ‚ÄúI really believe in that and what we have done, and to be able to kind of execute that stuff in a grand slam, second tournament of the year for me, will give me a lot of confidence, not just here but just going into the year.

‚ÄúI have always been the type of player where I get frustrated when I feel like I'm not getting better. And I still think that at my age, I've already had a lot of really great results. Being 31, I still feel like I'm improving as a player. So that is what gets me the most excited.‚Äù

title: Tony Romo goes viral after accidentally mentioning Patrick Mahomes
description: Tony Romo goes viral after accidentally mentioning Kansas City Chiefs quarterback Patrick Mahomes during the AFC Divisional broadcast | @EdEastonJr
fullText:
The Kansas City Chiefs did not qualify for the playoffs, yet they remain a hot topic during games. The latest example took place in the AFC Divisional round matchup between the Buffalo Bills and the Denver Broncos.

Former Pro Bowl quarterback and top CBS Sports game analyst Tony Romo was the subject of criticism on social media over the weekend. He accidentally called Josh Allen' Patrick Mahomes' during a highlight run in the Bills' loss to the Broncos. The seemingly harmless mistake drew attention from many, who questioned whether the former Dallas Cowboys star has a bias toward the Chiefs quarterback.

Tony Romo calls Josh Allen "Mahomes," hitting several Bingo card spaces all at once. pic.twitter.com/kzEB3weoWc

‚Äî Awful Announcing (@awfulannouncing) January 17, 2026

Chiefs games were prominently featured as the top CBS game for multiple weeks during the 2025 season until the team was out of playoff contention. The broadcast team was typically Romo, Jim Nantz, and Tracy Wolfson, so there is a strong familiarity with Kansas City in big games.

Romo will be back in the booth for the AFC Championship game between the Broncos and the New England Patriots. The game will be the first time since Mahomes became the full-time starter that Kansas City isn't involved in the matchup.

This article originally appeared on Chiefs Wire: Tony Romo goes viral after accidentally mentioning Patrick Mahomes

title: Kansas City Chiefs part ways with longtime Andy Reid associate
description: According to multiple reports, the Kansas City Chiefs parted ways with a longtime Andy Reid associate in the recent staff shake-up | @EdEastonJr
fullText:
The Kansas City Chiefs continue their coaching staff shake-up with another significant change. Head coach Andy Reid continues to readjust his staff after recently parting ways with long-time associate Todd Pinkson.

According to the Kansas City Star's Sam McDowell, Pinkston was let go after being hired by the team in 2023. The former wide receiver under Reid with the Philadelphia Eagles won a Super Bowl title with the Chiefs in his first season on the staff.

There are four changes to the Chiefs coaching staff so far, per sources:

They have fired RBs coach Todd Pinkston and WRs coach Connor Embree.

Louie Addazio chose to move on for the OL job at UNLV. Alex Whittingham has joined the Michigan staff.

Could be more after the carousel‚Ä¶

‚Äî Sam McDowell (@SamMcDowell11) January 15, 2026

The Chiefs have already parted ways with wide receiver coach Conner Embree and will be welcoming Eric Bieniemy as their new offensive coordinator. Pinkston's history with Reid dates back to his playing days, showing his loyalty to the system and signaling drastic changes after a disappointing 2025 season.

Kansas City's running game lacked explosion all season due to injuries, and big plays were rare from the position. Kareem Hunt and Isiah Pacheco led the team in rushing, with Hunt finishing with 611 yards and Pacheco with 462 yards. Rookie running back Brashard Smith contributed with 151 yards on the ground but proved to be a versatile threat in the passing game.

This article originally appeared on Chiefs Wire: Kansas City Chiefs part ways with longtime Andy Reid associate

title: Chiefs Threaten Kansas Exit Over $3 Billion Dispute as Clark Hunt & Ownership Demand a ‚ÄòLandlord‚Äô for New Stadium
description: The future of the Kansas City Chiefs‚Äô new home stadium is in jeopardy after a recent committee meeting involving Kansas lawmakers. The Chiefs announced plans for a new $3 billion domed stadium in December, where they proposed public ownership of the arena, as a significant percentage of the funding would be secured through sales tax revenue (STAR) bonds.
fullText:
The future of the Kansas City Chiefs‚Äô new home stadium is in jeopardy after a recent committee meeting involving Kansas lawmakers. The Chiefs announced plans for a new $3 billion domed stadium in December, where they proposed public ownership of the arena, as a significant percentage of the funding would be secured through sales tax revenue (STAR) bonds.

Hence, when questions were raised about why the stadium wasn‚Äôt privately owned, Chiefs attorney Korb Maxwell issued a statement confirming that, without public ownership, the proposal wouldn‚Äôt make sense for the franchise.

‚ÄúIf that (stadium) is not owned by a sports authority, if that is owned in private hands, then, if you would have $1.8 billion of STAR bonds come into that development, that would all be federally income taxed,‚Äù Maxwell said, as per the Kansas City Business Journal. ‚ÄúAnd so you would take, then, 45% of the dollars that came in and roughly ship that to Washington, D.C. ‚Ä¶ That would blow a huge hole in the budget for this project and, frankly, would not allow it to move forward.‚Äù

As explained by Korb Maxwell, private ownership would entail that the $1.8 billion in sales tax revenue (STAR) bonds could not be issued for the Chiefs‚Äô stadium on a tax-exempt basis. This would lead to a massive hit on the franchise‚Äôs budget for the stadium and, hence, would push the Chiefs to move away from their proposed plan.

These questions about public ownership of the stadium stem from the possibility of what would happen if the Kansas City Chiefs, who will be taking care of the arena, decide to leave. Responding to these concerns, the Chiefs‚Äô attorney reiterated the franchise‚Äôs long-term plans for the stadium.

‚ÄúWe‚Äôre absolutely doing this and planning this as the long, long-term home for the Kansas City Chiefs for (multiple) generations,‚Äù Maxwell said, as per theKansas City Business Journal.

With this statement, the Chiefs seem adamant about securing public ownership for their new stadium, as they believe this venture will be prosperous for the state of Kansas.

As plans for the new Kansas City Chiefs stadium were unveiled, team owner Clark Hunt shared why this decision to move from Arrowhead was taken. In his statement, Hunt explained how this new project will significantly benefit the fans and the state of Kansas.

‚ÄúWe made a decision as a family that this was the right opportunity and the best for the organization for several reasons,‚Äù Hunt said. ‚ÄúIt‚Äôs about the fans. My dad [Lamar Hunt, who founded the franchise] was always about the fans and thinking about the future.‚Äù

‚ÄúThis will give Chiefs Kingdom a state-of-the-art facility for multiple generations, a building that can last for at least 50 or 60 years. We believe it‚Äôs the best thing for the region. It will give Kansas City the opportunity to bid on events that we can‚Äôt host right now, like the Super Bowl, the College Football Playoff, and the NCAA Final Fours.‚Äù

As the Chiefs navigate the complex financing structure for their proposed $3 billion domed stadium, the franchise‚Äôs commitment to public ownership appears non-negotiable due to federal tax implications. Whether Kansas lawmakers will approve the necessary STAR bonds remains to be seen, but the Hunt family has made clear its vision extends generations into the future.

The post Chiefs Threaten Kansas Exit Over $3 Billion Dispute as Clark Hunt & Ownership Demand a ‚ÄòLandlord‚Äô for New Stadium appeared first on EssentiallySports.

title: Chiefs TE Travis Kelce reacts to the return of OC Eric Bieniemy
description: During the latest New Heights, Kansas City Chiefs tight end Travis Kelce reacted to the return of offensive coordinator Eric Bieniemy | @EdEastonJr
fullText:
During the recent episode of the New Heights podcast, Kansas City Chiefs tight end Travis Kelce shared his reaction to the return of offensive coordinator Eric Bieniemy.

"I love that s***. I think it's great. I think it's a marriage that's gonna pick up right where it left off. EB (Eric Bieniemy) and who he is as a coach, you can see kinda his personality and what he brings to the table on that Chicago team."

‚ÄúI can‚Äôt wait to see him back in the building he‚Äôs one of my favorite coaches of all time‚Äù

Travis shared his thoughts on (a possibly shirtless) Eric Bieniemy returning to the Chiefs pic.twitter.com/MRmdNAcIar

‚Äî New Heights (@newheightshow) January 21, 2026

Kansas City moved quickly to bring back Bieniemy after realizing Matt Nagy would move on for potential head coaching opportunities. Kelce expressed greater enthusiasm about Bieniemy's return, noting his anticipated appearance at the facility.

"I can't wait to see him back in the building, man. He's one of my favorite coaches of all time. He's one of my favorite people of all time," said Kelce, "I've had so many unbelievable growing moments under him as a player, as a person. I just love the guy. It's gonna be awesome to see him back in the building and see him back wearing the Chiefs' logo, baby."

Bieniemy spent nine years as an assistant coach and coordinator with Kansas City before joining the Washington Commanders as their offensive coordinator and assistant head coach for the 2023 season.

This article originally appeared on Chiefs Wire: Chiefs TE Travis Kelce reacts to the return of OC Eric Bieniemy

title: Chiefs' Offensive Coordinator Loses Out On Titans HC Job After Formal Interview
description: Titans opt for another candidate, keeping Nagy in Kansas City amidst offensive struggles and potential Mahomes absence.
fullText:
The Kansas City Chiefs won‚Äôt need to go looking for another offensive coordinator, at least for now, as current OC Matt Nagy lost out to Robert Salah to become the next head coach of the Tennessee Titans on Tuesday.

Nagy interviewed with the Titans over a week ago, causing many rumors of a departure to Tennessee that‚Äôd force the Chiefs to find a new OC in 2026. Perhaps that wouldn‚Äôt be the worst outcome for Kansas City, however, as the last couple of seasons haven‚Äôt been great in Kansas City on the offensive side of the ball.

We've completed in-person interviews with the following candidates. pic.twitter.com/Mctvgl2U5K

‚Äî Tennessee Titans (@Titans) January 20, 2026

There was no sign of the same dominant offense in Kansas City this past season. The Chiefs finished the season with 320.6 yards per game, only enough for 20th in the NFL. It‚Äôs only the second time the Chiefs haven't finished with at least 350 yards per game since Mahomes took over at QB.

It becomes even more alarming with the fact that the other season under 350 yards per game was in 2024, meaning the offense hasn‚Äôt been great in Kansas City for two consecutive seasons now. There‚Äôs no denying that the Chiefs, despite their dominance in the early 2020s, no longer instill the same fear into opponents from the offensive side of the ball.

It‚Äôs unfair to say the offensive troubles last season were entirely the fault of Nagy, however. In 2025, injuries and suspensions played a big role in the Chiefs‚Äô failures. It‚Äôs why Nagy has garnered a lot of interest this offseason as a name to fill the head coaching vacancies around the league.

Nagy has been with the Chiefs for several years, first starting with the team back in 2013. After his stint as the head coach for the Bears, Nagy immediately returned to Kansas City, playing a role in its last three Super Bowl appearances.

It looks like he‚Äôll be returning once again in 2026 despite the interest from the Titans, who ultimately chose Salejh, the defensive coordinator of the San Francisco 49ers. With Mahomes likely out for at least a portion of the 2026 season and several other question marks surrounding the offense, Nagy will certainly have his hands full come fall. In an offseason where there are looking to be several huge changes to the team, the Chiefs being able to keep Nagy will come as a breath of fresh air for the front office.

title: Falcons request interview with Kansas City Chiefs assistant GM
description: Report: Falcons request interview with Chiefs assistant GM Mike Bradway
fullText:
The Atlanta Falcons have been busy looking to fill their general manager vacancy, requesting five interviews over the last 24 hours. According to a report from NFL Network's Ian Rapoport, Kansas City Chiefs assistant general manager Mike Bradway is next on the list.

"The Falcons have requested to interview Chiefs assistant GM Mike Bradway for their GM job, sources say," wrote Rapoport. "A top lieutenant to GM Brett Veach, Bradway is next in a line of top KC personnel minds to explore a big job."

Bradway joined Kansas City's front office in 2018 as an assistant of player personnel. He held that role for three seasons before begin promoted to senior director of player personnel in 2021. Four years later, Bradway was promoted to his current role as the team's assistant general manager.

From 2008-2017, Bradway worked for the Philadelphia Eagles scouting department, forging a relationship with current Chiefs head coach Andy Reid.

The #Falcons have requested to interview #Chiefs assistant GM Mike Bradway for their GM job, sources say.

A top lieutenant to GM Brett Veach, Bradway is next in a line of top KC personnel minds to explore a big job. pic.twitter.com/hRLyNtHQSb

‚Äî Ian Rapoport (@RapSheet) January 21, 2026

The Falcons have been linked to four other candidates for their general manager vacancy, a few of whom previously interviewed for the team's new president of football role. Check out the list of reported interview requests below.

Kansas City Chiefs assistant GM Mike Bradway

Houston Texans¬†assistant GM James Liipfert

Chicago Bears assistant GM Ian Cunningham

San Francisco 49ers scouting/football director Josh Williams

Pittsburgh Steelers assistant GM Andy Wiedl

It was also reported by both ESPN and the NFL Network that the Falcons are hiring Tommy Rees as their new offensive coordinator. Rees spent the last two seasons working with head coach Kevin Stefanski in Cleveland, serving as the Browns offensive coordinator in 2025.
